comments.commentBody: Looks like your Deer John avatar garners a 7 point rating. It does LIVEN up the blog. Thanks.

Wait, we can actually do some math here. So Mr Abassi is a professional photographer, meaning he presumably had a pro flash for his camera. However, even the fastest flashes I believe have a recycling time of at least 2-3 seconds.

How can he take 49 shots with the flash if, by his own admission, there were only 10-15 seconds until the poor guy was hit by train? Sure weren't there just 5-6 flashes fired off, with the rest of the pics taken between recycling times?

Maybe he wanted to warn the driver, or maybe he just wanted to have a photo of that man on those tracks. Can we have a look at the EXIF data please?

I think that in the vast majority of such cases, people do step up to help - and the incident goes undocumented.  It's the rare cases, like this one, that turn out tragically and make the front pages.  People are assuming it's "typical New York," but in fact it's an anomaly.  Think about it: how many times has someone been killed on the tracks for lack of assistance?  Just this once, in my memory.

I hope that sometime this week, the theme of this story switches from who else was to blame, and who should have done this or could have done that to what people are actually supposed to do in these circumstances.

The MTA, the mayor's office, the Times, and the rest of the news media have a real opportunity to educate New Yorkers and tourists alike on what the proper thing to do if you:

- fall or are pushed on to the tracks and you have 10, 20, 30 or 60 seconds before a train reaches the station

- you are a bystander to this situation and you are 5, 10, 20 or 50 feet away from the person in trouble.

I have faith that this incident will get the ball rolling on educating the public on how to act if something like this happens again.

And I also hope that those who are looking to pin blame on others step back and realize how quickly all of this must have happened, and how surreal it must have been for anyone who saw it.
I went with SAFE house SAFE. Oh, well...
FIRE fit so well at 36 across! It was hard to believe it was wrong.

"Self-righteous writers like Noor will find fuel for the anti-semitic narrative they hold near and dear"

What utter nonsense. Your knee-jerk reaction of viewing every critic of Israeli policy through an anti-Semitic prism exemplifies a major problem entrenched in the pro-Israel crowd, as it impedes your ability to reach out to the other side or view this conflict from any perspective other than yours. It is understandable though as decades of bloodshed has sowed deep suspicions on both sides, and erasing these hostile sentiments will take more than a generation. This is why the Rabbis' position reflects such tremendous courage.

My comment was an attempt to explain current attitudes that permeate the clerical establishment in Saudi Arabia, and was not an endorsement of their views. The fact that Jews are not going away is old news, the real Newsflash here is that global patience is receding, and Israel may not be left with any allies if its current policies continue.

Jewish presence was tolerated more than a century ago, otherwise Jews in the diaspora would not have considered emigrating from a hostile Europe to a more hostile neighborhood. That gives me hope that a just resolution can help achieve a normal and healthy co-existence.

Why should that be surprising?

It happens: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim_supporters_of_Israel

Just as there is more than one jewish opinion, and more than one christian opinion, we should expect many arab opinions.

If each side only looks to the worst in the other says "See, they are all like that!" there will never be peace.

If we can all look at each other and bring ourselves to say "I'm sure you love your children too" then perhaps, one day, we can have peace.
Correction: The "world" hates powerful Jews; the world loves powerless or dead Jews. We saw this in the immediate aftermath of the 6 Day War.

Hey! I have a sweater vest on right now, The morning is chilly. Don't critize the sweater vest because of the person who wears one. Because Hitler and Stalin had mustaches doesn't mean that all who have one are like those two rogues. What's next- Bow ties?
Amen !

When I went to public schools in the 60s and 70s, there were no accommodations (I hate that word) for the disabled and very few disabled students in my classes.   I continue to this to be amazed by two blind high school students who, with no help from anyone really, overcame unbelievable obstacles just to go to school like "regular" people.  High school in the 60s was already nearly impossible to get through.   They did it.   By God they did it.  And thank God for Bob Dole's vision for an America where "all" have the right and access to participate equally and fully in every facet of society.  The ADA has changed our country in amazing ways.  Senators who voted against the treaty on trumped up fears and ramped up pressure from the Tea Party should be ashamed.  Santorum's vision for America is limited to people who think like he does, who are paranoid about black helicopters and world government, who define their own integrity devoid of charity and compassion and only by condemning others.   His is a sickeningly sweet, glib and smiling vision of an exclusive America.   I have thrown away my sweater vests.

"Any time peace negotiations seem to be heading somewhere, whoops, it's time for an intifida, a suicide bombing, a fraternal assassination to throw a wrench in the works, and try to gain more world sympathy for the underdogs"

That may be the case, especially if you rely on Fox News or Israel's Foreign Ministry's press releases to develop an understanding of the conflict.

What you conveniently leave out is the role played by Israel's right when they assassinated their own Prime Minister for being too peaceful, and the role the settler movement has played in hijacking the peace process. Reading the opinions of settler leader Dany Dayan (NY Times Op-Ed, July 25, 2012) or the less diplomatic chief Rabbi Ovadia Yosef may shed some light on the problem of racism that plagues both sides, and convince you that Arab leaders are not the only one who've contributed to the 'underdogs' status of Palestinians.
Proud of your continued leadership on Israel and social justice, BJ.  Thank you for your example and moral clarity and true commitment to Israel's enlightened self-interest.

Thanks to the New York Times people can judge for themselves. The new Politburo members seem mild mannered and intelligent. It is unfortunate that they have inherited a system that is ruthless. This new team of seven doesn’t seem interested in letting the people participate in an open system.  They are betting that the fire for democracy in the Middle East will not reach them. The Chinese who have tried to reform the government have paid the price. But the hour glass has been turned by the insightful writing of Jonathon Ansfield, David Barboza, Keith Bradsher, Andrew Jacobs, Ian Johnson, Jane Perlez, Edward Wong, and others. Thank you again.

Very sad story, a father having to hide his sons death. But as a report this feels incomplete, there has to be more - I cannot imagine a seasoned politician like Hu, being brought down on a subordinates mistake. Like in the Bo case, there has to be more than has been reported, something that could have brought Hu down.

Based on the month I spent working in China this past summer, I'd say the people know where things stand better than do most Americans. They know their media is suspect. They know their leaders are suspect.  They know the game is rigged for the powerful, that the money for all those Audis and Hummers is not going to come their way. They understand in ways many Americans don't now, and probably never will.
Regardless of the politics of the situation, this father and mother lost their only son, the future of their family.  It's very sad and my prayers are with them.

Yes, I fell for ETUI right out of the box.

On the other hand, rather quickly glommed onto the theme, but that did not alas make it any easier for me to complete - lots of minor errors.

I do like the perfect symmetry of BASES ... WATER ... ACIDS - nice theme puzzle.

adam
The Wallenda family is still at it -- I saw them here in CT last year. http://guilfordfair.org/the-flying-wallendas/

Then there is Nik Wallenda’s tightrope walk over Niagara’s Horseshoe Falls this past June. His sponsor, ABC TV, required the use of a tether, which he argued against but lost. Kinda took away from the stunt, but still…
Oops – that should have been NIAgara’s.

Base = alkali, from Arabic: 'al-qaly' (n., singular)
bases = alkalis or alkalies (n., plural)
basic = alkaline (adj.)
"The adjective 'alkaline' is commonly used in English as a synonym for 'base,' especially for soluble bases." - Wikipedia

All three theme answers: BASES, WATER and ACIDS, are placed according to their position on the PHSCALE, from high to low.

I'll never forget the horrifying fall of 73-year-old Karl WALLENDA of the "Flying Wallendas" in San Juan, Puerto Rico, 1978.

Excellent puzzle, tremendously enjoyable and Thursday-worthy.
I'm paraphrasing but some dude wrote about HOWIE takes a wise guy to play the fool.

Deb, As the saying goes, "There's no Fool like an Old Fool" and yours truly is April Fool #1. as I too, went with ETUI @1A!
Newly weds, Jeff and Jill took AVOW to love, honor and EBAY!
ASNER as I can tell, people who are on the Scent are simply following ODORS!
APHID your way at Burger King!

WIFI it, it's bigger than all of us!

Howie

Although the consequences of these acts may be unintended, they are completely foreseeable, just as with Fast and Furious. It is truly frightening to think that our government is so utterly stupid. Operation Wide Receiver (which was conducted with the Mexican government) was risky, but, probably could have been quite successful had it been handled professionally and competently by both Mexico and the U.S., but it wasn't, and we shouldn't have assumed that it would be. From the outset, Fast and Furious, which was conducted without the knowledge of Mexico, was a pitiful, bumbling fiasco. Ours was the perfect plan if we had wanted to arm and strengthen the drug cartels and the murder of innocents in Mexico and the U.S..

Arming rebels sounds good on the surface, but, if we are blind to the fact that the rebels are worse than the present dictator, it is incompetence. Most thinking people KNEW that the Muslim Brotherhood would take over the Egyptian elections/government. James Clapper, Director of U.S. National Intelligence, who called the Muslim Brotherhood a "secular organization" seemed to have been taken off guard when asked during a House Intelligence hearing if he was concerned that the Muslim Brotherhood would become a major player in Egyptian elections. He said that it is possible that it might play a very minor role, if any. He is either a great actor or a stooge. If Obama didn't know, he is incompetent; if he did know, he is ____ (fill in the blank).

Aranhas:  perhaps because the NYT Obama supporting public refuses to condemn Obama for any reason on foreign policy.  This board gives him the green light no matter what he does, and no criticism is tolerated without generating a response of racism.  No wonder Obama believes he's got the public on his side with endless drone bombing campaigns that are bankrupting this nation,

“This board gives him the green light no matter what he does, and no criticism is tolerated without generating a response of racism.”

A good, and valid point.

I wonder if those that immediately charge anyone with “racism” for valid critiques of Obama, would call Bill Clinton a racist, for having deemed Obama an “amateur” back in 08.

I seriously doubt it. The Slick One is their darling too.

Interesting how these things blow up in the President's face - any President.  Every act has unforeseen consequences, but shipping weapons to the mideast was just a replay of our experience shipping arms to Afghanistan to defeat the Russians and a totally stupid move.  Now they are used against us - again.  I wonder when Obama will be asked to return his Peach Prize.  I wonder when he'll start reading history books or hire someone who understands Santayana:  "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it."  Think Carter and the Shah of Iran.  Think Reagan and the Afghans.  Why is it so hard for our "leaders" to learn from the mistakes of the past?

The article assures us that "No evidence has surfaced that any weapons went to Ansar al-Shariah, an extremist group blamed for the Benghazi attack [that killed four Americans]."

It would be a colossal poetic justice, wouldn't it, if some of the arms supplied by Qatar and the emirates, with our consent, went to the Ansar al-Shariah extremist group.

We and our European blind followers conned the UN Security Council into approving a no-fly-zone resolution over Libya in order to "save" civilian life, just as we conned the UN, ourselves and the world about going to Iraq to search for WMDs.

In both Iraq and Libya, we won Pyrrhic victories, because what we've left behind are violent, unruly societies. Yet, without a scintilla of shame, our officials, think-tank "experts" and media talking heads proclaim our misadventures in Iraq and Libya to have been "successes."

And the same movie seems to be playing in Syria: outsiders supplying arms and money to all sidess for a mayhem that world powers could have prevented.

We need to remember that Hank Williams' admonition in his love song is equally relevant in world affairs: "Your cheating heart, will turn on you...."

Let's be fair.

I homeschooled my teen from first grade through high school while paying my taxes, including the portion that helps pay for everyone's education. No one defrayed my costs for books, field trips, learning aids, enrichment materials, movies, software, or anything else I bought over the years. One of the options I had was homeschooling via one of now many ISPs (Independent Study Program) or charter schools (one of them is owned by none other than former Bush official, William Bennett). Some of those ISPs provide their instruction online. Los Angeles Unified school district offers their high school students the option of getting their high school education online, free of charge. I am sure there are others, around the country, that do this. The curriculum follows the same state guidelines everyone else follows.

Homeschooling does not remove any responsibility from the tax payer. It also doesn't provide added benefits, either.

Children who are sick are entitled to be schooled under the home hospital provisions of IDEA. Federal education laws have a provision for children who are too sick to go to school that entitles them to be taught at home, while they recuperate. That's a good thing, one that by promoting the defeat of the UN treaty, he will prevent from encouraging in other nations to make the same kinds of provisions and safeguards we have had in place for years, in some cases.
So, what is the solution? Only provide books with one type of protagonist? Isn't that more likely to divide the country?

Absolutely yes. It LOOKS like intent on diversity, but underneath it is pure contempt and a belief that whatever minority group they focus on is so inferior, so lacking in imagination and drive, that they must be pandered to.

In the case of hispanics, in many parts of the country, they can't even be calle a "minority". At 25% of all school children, they will be the MAJORITY by the time they are adults.
All those books are pretty out there for little kids. Tolkien comes closest, but he's in no way on a third grade reading level. Try an eighth grade reading level instead.

I grew up in a very nice housing project in the Bronx, with no television and plenty of books.  I read books about white children with intact families who lived near the sea, while I lived (and continue to live) near Long Island Sound.  I entered first grade a very fluent reader and writer, having only white main characters as my reading models and not much else.  In junior high school, I read Dante's Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradisio (more Europeans, but still very, very fascinating).  My reading skills clearly did not suffer as a result of this.  It wasn't until high school in the 1970's when I was exposed to Richard Wright, Zora Neale Hurston and other great African American writers.  I am currently a middle school English teacher, whose reluctant readers have become less reluctant because they seem to have some connections to the characters they read.  My students read the Blueford High series, Walter Dean Myers, Jacqueline Woodson, Gary Soto, Piri Thomas, and yes, Judy Blume, Rick Riordan, and Suzanne Collins.  I'm not quite sure what it takes to get our children reading more, but I'm not ready to give up just yet.  My personal love of reading is a tiny part of it, because I strive to make every book seem like an adventure ready to happen.   The current crop of literature has a ton (in my opinion) of multicultural writers, themes and characters.  It is up to parents, students, and educators to share them.
